ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I devloped intiuiton in reagrds to current technology. I learned about practical solutions to environmental challenges currently faced. I was most impressed with learning about the current technological infrastructure Yale has.
History of modern technology. Kroon Hall, ecars, autonomous vehicles, biomedical engineering, climate change, energy

We learned about the science behind a range of technologies, from energy, to e-cars, lazars, radar, medical tech, and more. You will also learn presentation skills with the help of the TA, as the final project is a powerpoint presentation to the class on a technology of your choosing.
I learned about energy, with many guest speakers discussing the future, whether it was about AI, energy, medtech, etc.
I learned about a lot of different types of modern technology and their impacts on the world.

I really enjoyed learning about the real world applications of some of the science concepts we talked about. From e-cars to spectroscopy, learning about Tesla and medical imaging was incredibly interesting.

A wide variety of information about modern technology, covering basic functioning of things like nanotechnology, computers, and electric cars to the discussion of current applications of many of these technologies. Also learned about a variety of related fields through interesting guest lectures from Yale or Professor Prober associated people. Lastly, we had a final project where we learned and presented about the careers of retired Yale faculty.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
One strength is that the number of students are low enough so that each student may get individual attention. 

One weakness is that with online courses, time differences were tough to keep track of all classes.

Looking back I enjoyed the class. To keep it real, lecture can be very boring at times. But Prober is an expert in the field who really enjoys the material, and he cares about the class. He's there on cell or by email all of the time, and cares about his students and their well beings. Material is also interesting if you take the time to learn about it yourself.

Cons: I have no idea what my grade is in the class. Class isn't well structured; poorly defined criteria for psets, presentations. If the TF is Tom, prepare to put in a LOT of work. Lots of points taken off by TF for silly reasons that don't make sense. But the class is 110% doable, I'd say go for it.
The course's organization made it tough to follow. Concrete units that divide the course into definitive subtopics might help with this.
I think because it was online, it was hard to focus sometimes. I enjoyed Professor Prober and it was an enjoyable class, but my focus levels werent always there.
I think the course was very educational and the projects were good.
The online environment made the class slightly less than fully engaging. But, the smaller seminar made the class much more interesting than a lecture style class.

The course's strengths include being engaging, current, and generally, something that you'd like to listen to even if not as a part of the class. We also got the rare opportunity to hear from experts in various fields about the new and exciting things being explored in these fields today. A thing that could be improved which is relatively minor is the structure of the problem sets for this course. There weren't many, but I felt they were sometimes overly robotic with a good amount of 'google' questions (although notably this was especially the case for the first pset, and decreased each one after). I liked the questions that were critical thinking based on information learned in class which I felt were much more useful and engaging.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Prober was a good guy. I like the online format, please continue.
I honestly dont know. This year was so random and things just kind of happened. I think hopefully once school starts back up in person it will be different.
I think everything was good but having Zoom group presentations was a bit tricky.
Guest lectures were great as they introduced variety into seemingly endless zoom calls.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, This was a wonderful first year seminar that engages on current technology and the scientific laws. This was a great science course for a non science major.

Yeah, I'd recommend it to be honest. It's a low-stress course that's what you make of it. If you want to learn, all the opportunity is there in the world for you to learn more about applied physics. Our class wasn't APHY majors so interest level was low, but if you can take this class with a friend or have a passion for this stuff I'd recommend it. If you have four credits on your worksheet, just add this one. Easy credit to get here at Yale
Yes. A good introduction to science and tech for humanities students that are hesitant about the sciences. There are 3 p-sets, a midterm, and a final project, so the workload is manageable.
Yes, if you want a basis in energy and want a science credit.
Yes, I think Prof Prober did a great job and I was really interested in the subjects that we talked about
Yes, but the applicability of psets could be improved. I wished they werent mainly focused on google searches.

Definitely, especially for those who need a science credit and don't want to take an intensive, in-depth science course but would rather learn about modern technology that is actively being used and developed in the real world.

comments: Keep it virtual
Same, Zoom
